Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Translator made significant errors affecting credibility determinations, including mistranslations about border crossing and educational background; applicant was unaware of errors during hearing.
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate translation during refugee hearing undermining procedural fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Significant translation errors not corrected during hearing
Credibility_Assessment: Errors affected the Board's credibility findings
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to adequate translation under Section 14 of the Charter
Decision_Rationale: Translation errors were significant and undermined procedural fairness, even if they did not directly alter key findings; applicant could not waive rights due to lack of awareness.
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness, bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent statements, lack of credible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(2) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Revocation of passport and five-year ban
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No obligation to provide translation services; non-disclosure of irrelevant information
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Draft letters (deemed not indicative of bias)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, absence of bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Passport revocation and five-year ban upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in passport use and application

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness, bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants facilitated fraud by impostors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Payment records, false applications, investigation findings
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(2) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Revocation due to allowing impostors to use passports
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Payment of $10,000 per impostor, complicity in fraud
Crimes.Application_Error: Provided false information in replacement applications
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, absence of bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Unauthorized use of passport by impostors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing false information in support of a passport application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent statements, failure to respond to inquiries
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(2) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in passport application process

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness, bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Administrative Law
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants allowed misuse of passports
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No procedural breach; evidence supported conclusion
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, absence of bias, reasonableness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in immigration and passport context

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Applicant does not speak English; interpreter errors affected key factual details such as dates and actions (e.g., 'pulled' vs. 'carried'); errors influenced credibility findings
Procedural_Issue: Interpreter errors during hearing
Evidence_Used: Transcript of hearing, expert affidavit on interpretation quality
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate interpretation leading to factual inaccuracies in the record
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding by the Board influenced by interpreter errors
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by the Board
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, overturned decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to a fair hearing under s. 14 of the Charter
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with correctness for Charter issues
Decision_Rationale: Interpreter errors violated the applicant's right to a fair hearing, undermining the reliability of the credibility assessment
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants' right to a fair hearing, specifically their right to an interpreter, met procedural fairness standards
Governing_Law: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Evidence_Assessment: Post-hearing analysis revealed significant interpretation errors that altered the applicants' statements
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the judicial review; case remanded for rehearing with a qualified interpreter
Credibility_Factor: Adverse credibility findings due to poor interpretation affecting testimony
Legal_Rule: Section 14 guarantees the right to an interpreter; interpretation must be continuous, precise, competent, impartial, and contemporaneous
Grounds_for_Claim: Infringement of the right to a fair hearing due to inadequate interpretation services
Outcome_on_Merits: Applicants' rights were found to be infringed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants' rudimentary French knowledge, request for interpreter, discrepancies in interpretation during hearing, post-hearing analysis of interpretation errors
Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, rehearing with qualified interpreter
Outcome: Case remanded to a differently constituted panel for redetermination with proper interpretation
Legal_Provision: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of natural justice in immigration proceedings
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Principles of natural justice in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged poor interpretation during appeal hearing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of natural justice found
Crimes.Institutional_Action: IAD's refusal to reopen the case
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Deportation appeal based on criminal conviction
Crimes.Credibility: Claim of interpretation errors assessed as trivial

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of reoffending or danger assessed through immigration lens
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential threat due to violent offense
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support conviction and deportation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged in immigration appeal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code - Assault with a weapon

Application_Facts: Applicant faced poor translation during the hearing, impacting credibility assessment; significant discrepancies in interpretation affecting key details of his claim.
Procedural_Issue: Poor quality of translation affected the applicant's ability to present his case effectively
Evidence_Used: Evidence showing significant discrepancies in interpretation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Translation errors undermining reliability of evidence and testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility assessment was impacted due to inaccurate translation
Outcome: Decision overturned, case referred back for rehearing
Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness caused by translation issues
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) or equivalent decision-making body

Application_Facts: Applicant did not object to interpreter issues during the first and third days of the hearing despite being aware of problems.
Errors identified by an independent interpreter were immaterial to the Board's credibility findings.
The second day's administrative nature did not affect the outcome.
Misrepresentation_Element: Inadequate interpretation claimed to have affected fairness, but no timely objection was made.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to raise interpreter concerns at the first reasonable opportunity.
Evidence_Used: Testimony from hearings, independent interpreter review of translation accuracy.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No material deficiency found; translation errors did not impact key findings.
Credibility_Assessment: Translation issues did not undermine the overall credibility assessment.
Decision_Outcome: No breach of natural justice occurred.
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee claim decision based on alleged interpretation inadequacies.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation in refugee hearings must be continuous, precise, competent, impartial, and contemporaneous.
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to object promptly; translation errors were immaterial to credibility findings.

Dispute_Type: Credibility dispute arising from alleged inadequate interpretation affecting testimony.
Legal_Issue: Whether discrepancies in testimony and documents due to poor interpretation constitute a breach of natural justice.
Credibility_Assessment: Translation errors did not affect key credibility findings such as sister's death date or document authenticity.
Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, documentary evidence, interpreter performance evaluation.
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant claimed inadequate translation led to negative credibility findings.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Timing of objections to interpretation — failure to raise issue at first reasonable opportunity.
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of refugee protection decision.
Application_Error: Perceived inconsistencies in testimony attributed to interpretation, but not substantiated as material.
Assessment_Standard: Interpretation must be continuous, precise, competent, impartial, and contemporaneous.
Legal_Standard: Breach of natural justice requires material impact on fairness of proceedings.
Application_Factor: Awareness of interpretation issues without timely objection.
Decision_Outcome: No breach of natural justice found.

Dispute_Type: Authenticity of submitted documents in refugee claim.
Legal_Issue: Whether fabrication of documents undermined credibility and justified rejection of claim.
Outcome: Refugee claim denied; application for judicial review dismissed.
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant lacked credibility due to fabricated documents including altered dates and handwritten changes.
Evidence_Type: Government-issued documents, forensic analysis of document alterations.
Basis_of_Claim: Submission of fraudulent documents to prove family member’s death and fear of persecution.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Presence of altered, incomplete, or implausible documentation affecting trustworthiness.
Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection proceeding and subsequent judicial review.
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court on review.
Application_Error: Submission of knowingly false or manipulated documents.
Assessment_Standard: Documents must be genuine and trustworthy; fraud impacts overall credibility.
Legal_Standard: Credibility can be rejected if supported by objective inconsistencies and document fraud.
Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected due to lack of credibility stemming from document fraud.
Document_Fraud: Altered dates, handwritten changes, omissions in official documents.

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant sought refugee status, which was denied twice by the same PRRA Officer.
Procedural_Issue: Alleged bias due to same officer handling both applications; procedural fairness concerns under natural justice
Evidence_Used: PRRA application materials, credibility assessments, officer's findings
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility assessment reviewed for reasonableness; court found no error in assessment
Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA decision based on alleged bias and credibility errors
Legal_Standard_Applied: Principles of natural justice and impartiality
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of bias; credibility assessment was reasonable and within acceptable limits

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.24
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's status expired on December 31, 2009; claimed preservation under IRPR s.183(5), which did not apply post-2009
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to leave Canada as directed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, immigration file, departure instructions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer correctly identified inadmissibility due to criminal conviction and overstaying; reasons were brief but sufficient

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer made errors in refusing TRP due to impaired driving conviction
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s.24, risk vs. need assessment for TRP
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for impaired driving, failure to depart Canada
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify TRP issuance
Crimes.Legal_Rule: TRPs may be granted under exceptional circumstances at officer’s discretion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged factual or legal errors in TRP refusal
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal conviction, immigration history, non-compliance with departure directive
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and IRPR provisions on inadmissibility and TRPs
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant challenged refusal via judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official records, conviction documents, immigration file
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn TRP refusal

Application_Facts: Applicant lacked sufficient physical presence in Canada but maintained family and business ties
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient accumulation of 1095 days of residence over four years
Procedural_Issue: Failure of the citizenship judge to specify which residency test was applied (quantitative, qualitative, or centralized mode of living)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear reasoning on how residency requirement was satisfied
Outcome: Appeal granted; application remitted for re-determination by a different judge
Relief_Sought: Review of citizenship approval based on unclear residency assessment
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of residency compliance with proper reasoning
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of clarity and transparency in applying residency tests

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to provide evidence of research or understanding of the markets for his proposed businesses; gave vague responses indicating insufficient planning
Misrepresentation_Element: Insufficient planning and lack of credible business proposal
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Officer acted within jurisdiction by assessing business viability
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of market research, unclear business plan
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's responses were vague and indicated lack of preparation
Legal_Standard_Applied: Demonstration of viable business contributing to Canada's economy
Decision_Rationale: Applicant unable to prove business viability during interview

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection, filed a PRRA application, claim rejected due to credibility issues, new evidence did not substantiate additional risks
Procedural_Issue: Lack of in-person interview
Insufficient analysis connecting risk to applicant's profile
Evidentiary_Deficiency: New evidence did not substantiate additional risks
Lack of connection between evidence and applicant’s specific profile
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility findings questioned for procedural fairness
Credibility cited as basis for rejection
Outcome: Decision remanded for reconsideration by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk to life under sections 96 and 97
Decision_Rationale: Officer's conclusions were unreasonable
Analysis lacked adequate connection to applicant's specific circumstances

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (liberty rights)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 7; Crown Liability and Proceedings Act; Federal Court Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for interlocutory injunction or stay in Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff voluntarily joined training program; release was discretionary; grievance process incomplete; no evidence of contractual obligation to grant leave
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to show serious issue arising under Section 7
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not explicitly challenged; focus on legal entitlement rather than credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 7 protects liberty, but no positive obligation on Crown to grant discretionary release; injunctive relief against Crown is restricted
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Serious issue to be tried; appropriateness of injunctive relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of leave/voluntary release to pursue graduate studies
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Training agreement, request for leave, refusal by authorities, ongoing grievance procedure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Charter rights vs. administrative discretion in military/service obligations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No legal or contractual obligation to release plaintiff; proper procedures followed
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Injunction or stay to prevent enforcement of duty reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Terms of service agreement under Medical Officer Training Plan
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 7; Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, Section 22
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiff sought leave to pursue further studies; request denied; failed to report for duty
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ongoing grievance process; premature judicial intervention
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over Charter claims and injunctive relief against Crown
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Service agreement, request for leave, denial letter, grievance filing
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of legal entitlement to release or breach of contract
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; decision based on legal interpretation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Injunctive relief to prevent enforcement of duty reporting
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay or injunction based on alleged Charter violation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue under Section 7 of the Charter
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Serious issue to be tried standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal or contractual right to release; voluntary commitment; grievance process not exhausted

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee protection criteria under changed country conditions
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on past political persecution in Ukraine; Board found country conditions improved post-Orange Revolution; past mistreatment deemed 'abhorrent' but not 'atrocious'
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in the Board’s assessment
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, evidence of political changes in Ukraine, documentation of past mistreatment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish compelling reasons under §108(4) due to lack of severity in past persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on changed circumstances rather than credibility
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; applicants remain non-refugees
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Decision_Rationale: Country conditions in Ukraine have fundamentally changed; no compelling reasons exist under IRPA §108(4) to maintain refugee status despite past persecution
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 and Section 101(1)(a) regarding refugee protection eligibility
Governing_Law: International Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Two Hungarian Roma families claimed persecution in Hungary due to their ethnicity and lack of effective state protection
Claimant_Status: Applicants for refugee protection in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Claimants were in Canada and formally applied for refugee status
Procedural_Issue: Excessive documentation demands
Failure to conduct proper credibility assessment
Insufficient reasoning on state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence of systemic discrimination and violence against Roma in Hungary
Reports on ineffective law enforcement response in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board Member failed to adequately consider evidence of lack of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable negative credibility findings made without sufficient basis
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claims initially rejected by Refugee Protection Division
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was unreasonable due to inadequate analysis of state protection and flawed credibility assessment
Actual effectiveness of state protection must be assessed, not just legislative efforts
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Violation_Type: Application refusal based on lack of personalized risk and new evidence
Application_Facts: Officer found no personalized risk or new evidence rebutting Inadmissibility for Foreign Nationals (IFA); applicant claimed procedural unfairness and incorrect assessment of humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking permanent residency or relief from removal
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness regarding use of extrinsic evidence
Evidence_Used: Assessment of risk, establishment in Canada, family ties in Mexico, credibility and supporting documentation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of new or compelling evidence to rebut IFA or support H&C claim
Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably assessed applicant's credibility as insufficient to establish risk or strong H&C grounds
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Officer's decisions upheld as reasonable
Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA and H&C rejections, finding of procedural unfairness
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of unreasonable decision, referral back for re-determination
Decision_Rationale: No personalized risk established; procedural fairness breach did not affect outcome; H&C factors balanced with stronger family ties in Mexico
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer responsible for PRRA and H&C assessments

Violation_Type: Failure to meet criteria for Convention refugee status
Application_Facts: Perger family claimed persecution in Hungary due to Roma ethnicity; attack on female applicant deemed isolated; six-year delay in leaving Hungary unexplained
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimants left Hungary after alleged persecution
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Used: Details of attack on female applicant, timeline of events, country conditions in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Unexplained six-year delay in leaving Hungary, lack of evidence showing ongoing risk or pattern of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Fear of persecution not found to be objectively well-founded
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees, reversal of IRB decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Decision_Rationale: Attack was isolated and not atrocious or appalling; no compelling reasons arising from previous persecution under subsection 2(3); delay in fleeing undermined objective basis for fear
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee status criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Sierra Leone due to civil war and sought refugee status in Canada; visa officer determined their experiences were part of generalized conflict, not targeted persecution; conflict had ended and conditions improved in Sierra Leone
Claimant_Status: Foreign national seeking refugee status abroad
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – applicants were outside Canada seeking entry
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging visa officer’s refusal of refugee application
Evidence_Used: Evidence of improved conditions in Sierra Leone, end of civil conflict
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicants did not demonstrate targeted persecution or lack of durable solution
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer's refusal of refugee status upheld
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; applicants remain ineligible for refugee status
Relief_Sought: Grant of refugee status and admission to Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Criteria for Convention refugee abroad or humanitarian-protected person class under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The applicants' experiences were part of a generalized conflict rather than targeted persecution; country conditions in Sierra Leone had improved, allowing for safe repatriation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper exclusion under s. 114(2) due to 'organized plan' and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentations noted but humanitarian factors outweighed
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's jurisdictional error in applying rigid guidelines
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Holistic evaluation of humanitarian and compassionate factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Plaintiffs' establishment in Canada, family ties, and integration
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory discretion under s. 114(2) cannot be unduly restricted by guidelines
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Entitled to new hearing before different officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or visa documentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Lawfulness of excluding applicants based on 'organized plan'
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of entry method and residency establishment
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Truthfulness of entry claims and integration in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Ministerial guidelines cannot override statutory discretion
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Reliance on 'organized plan' exclusion in guidelines

Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs overstayed visas and applied under H&C program
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant past status, compliant present integration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Generally credible despite initial violations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper denial based on 'organized plan' and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentation found but mitigated by humanitarian factors
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Establishment in Canada and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Jurisdictional error in rigid guideline application
Crimes.Application_Error: Denial based solely on 'organized plan' without H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Integration, employment, family ties in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory discretion prevails over restrictive guidelines
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior misrepresentation and mode of entry

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to depart after visa expiration
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs remained beyond authorized stay and applied for permanent residency
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged participation in organized entry scheme
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible claimants despite immigration violations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Guidelines must not override statutory intent

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was present in Canada for only 584 days within the four years preceding the application, falling short of the required 1,095 days
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on record; no obligation to justify use of physical presence test
Evidence_Used: Record before the Citizenship Judge, including evidence of applicant's establishment in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of physical presence and residential ties
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship or reassessment of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test (quantitative approach) under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the statutory physical presence requirement and properly assessed that the applicant did not meet the 1,095-day residency requirement

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with removal order due to custody arrangement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant, a Nigerian citizen, has two Canadian-born children; Ontario Court granted her custody and prohibited child removal from Ontario; removal officer argued deportation does not contravene custody order as physical proximity is not required.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Nigerian citizen with custody of Canadian-born children
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No – subject to removal order after failed refugee and humanitarian claims
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether Ontario custody order triggers automatic stay under IRPA Section 50(a)
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Conflict between provincial family court order and federal immigration enforcement authority
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Ontario Court custody order, removal order, submissions by Minister
Crimes.Outcome: Removal stayed temporarily pending appeal resolution or expiration of appeal period
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Prevention of deportation based on custody rights
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal under IRPA Section 50(a)
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 50(a) of IRPA – enforcement must directly contravene a judicial decision where the Minister had opportunity to make submissions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Custody order does not require physical presence; deportation does not 'directly contravene' the order; precedent does not support such interpretation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA Section 50(a) and general residency provisions
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada on temporary status, overstayed visa after unsuccessful refugee and humanitarian claims; obtained Ontario custody order for Canadian-born children; argued removal violates court order.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Nigerian citizen, former temporary resident, parent of Canadian citizens
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No – overstayed visa and subject to removal
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Interpretation of IRPA Section 50(a) in relation to family court orders
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Overlap between immigration enforcement and provincial family law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa history, refugee claim records, humanitarian application outcome, Ontario custody order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Cancellation of removal order based on best interests of children and custody rights
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal under IRPA Section 50(a), protection under Charter and international conventions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 50(a) of IRPA – requirement of direct contravention of judicial decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Deportation does not directly contravene custody order; physical proximity not mandated by order; prior jurisprudence rejects similar arguments

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Congolese citizen with multiple unsuccessful refugee and humanitarian applications; officer found insufficient evidence of unusual hardship upon return to DRC; applicant demonstrated adaptability in Canada but that alone does not justify permanent residency.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed reasonableness of decision under IRPA Section 25
Evidence_Used: International human rights instruments, applicant's circumstances, history of applications
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of unusual hardship or personal risk upon return to the Democratic Republic of the Congo
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no Charter violation found
Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to demonstrate unusual hardship or personal risk upon return to the DRC; adaptability in Canada not sufficient to grant permanent residency
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, Federal Court (for judicial review)

Application_Facts: Khan was 57 days short of the 1,095-day physical presence requirement; maintained family ties and economic contributions in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum 1,095 days of physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge's decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence, family ties, economic contributions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documented physical presence days
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found the Citizenship Judge's strict interpretation unreasonable
Outcome: Appeal allowed; case remitted for reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Reevaluation of residency under a contextual approach
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residence in Canada over four years under s 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Residency should be assessed contextually, considering factors beyond strict physical presence, especially in exceptional circumstances

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 114 or s. 129
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged errors in fact-finding during H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Applicant claims incorrect facts used (e.g., sponsorship eligibility)

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 114 or s. 129
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged factual inaccuracies in H&C decision (e.g., spouse's sponsorship ability)
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Factual errors claimed but not proven to cause irreparable harm

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a narcotic for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to family member’s criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA, s. 36(2)(a) – family member inadmissible on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant has three Canadian-born children; husband (PR) convicted of drug offenses
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant is foreign national seeking H&C relief

Legal_Issue: Was the decision to revoke Mr. Clue's Transportation Security Clearance (TSC) procedurally fair and supported by evidence?
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Clue was uncooperative during investigations
Evidence_Type: Alleged placement of a loaded handgun on an aircraft
Legal_Provision: Section related to TSC under Aeronautics Act
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged involvement in placing a loaded handgun on an aircraft

Violation_Type: Potential unlawful interference with civil aviation
Application_Facts: Alleged involvement in loading a handgun onto an aircraft
Uncooperative behavior
Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness in revocation process
Credibility_Assessment: Uncooperative attitude
Decision_Rationale: Reasonable belief of potential security threat

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and evidentiary support for TSC revocation

Credibility_Assessment: Positive
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Potential breach in assessment of personalized risk
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Possibly found due to mischaracterization of risk

Credibility_Assessment: Positive
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Non-compliance with immigration status after fleeing persecution
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Mexico due to threats
Procedural_Issue: Board's failure to properly assess risk
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board dismissed personalized nature despite credible evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants deemed credible
Decision_Rationale: Risk was particularized, not generalized

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on criminal victimization
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Insufficient reasoning on personalization of risk

Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found credible

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether detention review decisions contained reviewable errors regarding release conditions and flight risk assessment
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Subsection 58(1); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRP Regulations), Section 248
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Identity concerns initially present, but mitigated by new surety and family presence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Length of detention, unexplained delays, alternatives to detention, bond amount, surety, family ties
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Detention based on identity deception and people smuggling involvement
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Recent changes reducing flight risk: family presence, increased bond, new surety
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of immigration detention review decisions
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged error in assessing flight risk and release conditions
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Release unless danger to public or unlikely to appear for removal
Crimes.Application_Factor: Flight risk, identity concerns, security risks, inadmissibility for organized criminality
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division, Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border documents upon arrival

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave Canada after temporary status expired
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.24(1) - failure to comply with conditions or departure order
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Subsection 58(1); IRP Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent detained for 19 months due to unresolved PRRA and inadmissibility issues
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to immigration detention
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to prolonged stay beyond authorized period
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Delays in processing PRRA and lack of clear timeline for removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties in Canada, surety, ongoing legal processes, length of detention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Cooperative with authorities, stable community connections
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Detention justified only if danger to public or unlikely to appear
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Prolonged detention without foreseeable end not justified given mitigating factors

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention review based on inadmissibility for organized criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA s.37(1)(a) - inadmissibility for organized criminality
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence considered included travel document signing, surety, curfew compliance
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review of Immigration Division decisions
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Involvement in people smuggling via MV Sun Sea
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Arrival by irregular maritime vessel (MV Sun Sea)
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Deemed inadmissible for organized criminality related to smuggling
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Security risk and moderate flight risk
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Balancing flight risk against evolving personal circumstances and lengthy detention
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s.58(1), s.37; IRP Regulations s.248

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the tripartite test for a stay of removal: serious issue, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 48(2)
Crimes.Outcome: Stay granted until humanitarian and compassionate application resolved
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of returning to St. Lucia due to domestic abuse and lack of support for children's medical needs
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children, state protection, risk from ex-partner
Crimes.Application_Error: Officer failed to consider best interests of children and available state protection
Evidence_Ignored: Available state protection in St. Lucia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience

Crimes.Violation_Type: Overstay of authorized period of stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections related to temporary resident status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, has pending H&C application, fears domestic abuse in St. Lucia
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all relevant factors in deferral decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer focused only on practicality, ignored child welfare and risks
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permission to remain in Canada during H&C processing
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness under IRPA, tripartite test for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Serious issue, irreparable harm to children, balance of convenience favors applicant

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections on removal orders and compliance
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after removal order due to fear of domestic violence and lack of state protection
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Removed person who failed to depart
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Best interests of children and risks in St. Lucia not considered
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remain in Canada until H&C decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard, tripartite test for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant meets all three branches of the stay test

Crimes.Violation_Type: Actions placing children at risk upon removal
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA considerations regarding best interests of children
Crimes.Application_Facts: Removal would expose children to risks due to domestic violence, medical needs, and separation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Irregular status due to pending proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess child protection concerns in removal decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Best interests of children ignored by officer
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Protection for children from harm due to removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test for stay of removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of irreparable harm to children if removed

Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – ongoing threat to life and safety
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm upon return
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – specific threats from known individual
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Considered under IRPA s. 117(9) for H&C grounds

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Foreseeable risk of violence after verbal altercation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reliable based on officer documentation and procedural gaps

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Duty of Care under Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether CSC breached its duty of care to ensure inmate safety
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Officer reports and security deficiencies deemed credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: CSC must take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm
Standard_of_Review: Palpable and overriding error for factual findings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to act on pre-indicators of violence and inadequate security
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, Corrections and Conditional Release Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in applying s. 109(1) and (2) of IRPA regarding misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 109(1) and (2)
Crimes.Outcome: RPD's decision set aside, new hearing ordered
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inadequate assessment of respondent's citizenship status
Crimes.Evidence_Type: New evidence related to Russian citizenship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Improper consideration of new evidence under s. 109(2)
Crimes.Application_Error: RPD improperly considered new evidence under s. 109(2)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether decision was based on material misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictions in citizenship status not adequately addressed
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False representation of citizenship in immigration documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in considering new evidence under s. 109(2) of IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 109(1) and (2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Improper consideration of new evidence on citizenship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, new hearing ordered
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to prove misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 109(2) prohibits reassessing old evidence with new evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of RPD decision on citizenship misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD erred in applying s. 109(1) and (2) of IRPA regarding fraud in obtaining documents
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 109(1) and (2)
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, new hearing ordered
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure to properly assess credibility of citizenship claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of Russian citizenship to obtain immigration benefits
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of fraudulent information in document acquisition
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Impact of misrepresentation on refugee status eligibility
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Acquisition of immigration documents through false citizenship claims

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Zündel remained in Canada beyond the validity of his visa, contributing to concerns about his legal status.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-citizen, permanent resident subject to security assessment
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Review of admissibility through security certificate process
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central to this charge; focus was on security grounds
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deemed inadmissible due to security concerns linked to continued presence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal or cancellation of security certificate
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the certificate's reasonableness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of inadmissibility based on credible evidence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Continued presence combined with security risks justified inadmissibility
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Solicitor General of Canada and Minister of Citizenship and Immigration

Crimes.Victim_Status: Targeted groups: racial, ethnic, and religious minorities
Crimes.Location_of_Incident: Global dissemination via website; impact in Canada
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Extensive reach of propaganda, leadership role in white supremacist networks
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Claims of non-violence and free speech defense
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of promoting Holocaust denial and anti-Semitic materials
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of radicalization and incitement
Crimes.Risk_Type: Ideological extremism leading to potential violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Long-term societal harm through hate promotion
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Website content, communications, financial support records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Zündel failed to refute key allegations during hearings
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – immigration consequence rather than criminal sentence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a danger to the security of Canada
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Poses a threat through extremist ideology and global influence
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Serious possibility of inspiring violence and radicalization
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Associations with violent white supremacist groups
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Promotion of hate, direction of extremist adherents, ideological leadership
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian social cohesion and national security
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Recognized leader and influencer within neo-Nazi circles
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of classified evidence reviewed by designated judge
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Classified intelligence, public propaganda, financial and communication records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Zündel’s explanations were insufficient to counter evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of cooperation on key relationships and activities
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Serious possibility standard under administrative law

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization that engages in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Affiliation with organizations promoting terrorism and violence
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: High risk due to ideological alignment and material support
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Global network of extremist associates advocating violence
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Financing, directing, and supporting terrorist-adjacent organizations
Crimes.Target_Entity: Democratic values and public safety in Canada
Crimes.Organization_Involved: International white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Influential figure providing ideological and logistical support
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Strong and corroborated by classified and public sources
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on classified intelligence with limited disclosure
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, digital communications, financial trails
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Allegations not credibly challenged by Zündel
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Failure to clarify key associations during proceedings
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Serious possibility based on credible evidence

Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking

Legal_Issue: Exclusion from refugee status under Article 1E of the Refugee Convention

Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ability to return to and receive protection from Germany

Crimes.Institutional_Action: Board assessed applicant's failure to access state protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant recruited and fundraised for the OLF over seven years
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Recruitment and fundraising activities supporting OLF
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Activities contradicted claims of minimal involvement
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board found reasonable grounds to believe membership
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds to believe membership under subsection 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Broad definition of membership includes material support such as recruitment and fundraising

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe engages, has engaged or will engage in acts of terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Involvement with OLF, an organization linked to terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential support for terrorist activities through recruitment and funding
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: OLF reasonably believed to engage in terrorism
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Seven years of sustained support to OLF
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Recruiting and fundraising for a proscribed organization
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Active participation through recruitment and fundraising
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence of support activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of minimal involvement not credible given duration and nature of activities
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Duration (7 years), consistency of actions, material support provided
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'membership' in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada due to national security concerns

Legal_Issue: Did the Officer err by failing to exercise discretion and ignoring relevant evidence regarding deferral?
Legal_Provision: IRPA - enforcement of removal orders unless deferral requested with sufficient evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged health concerns not formally submitted
Legal_Standard: Onus on applicant to provide justification for deferral
Application_Factor: Failure to submit formal request or evidence

Legal_Issue: Did the Officer err in law by failing to exercise discretion and ignoring relevant evidence?
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants failed to provide documentary evidence
Legal_Rule: Officers must enforce removal orders unless deferral is requested with sufficient evidence

Key_Evidence_Considered: Officer's notes indicating no deferral request
Legal_Provision: IRPA - timely enforcement of removal orders

Evidence_Type: Claim of targeting due to perceived wealth

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in an organization with a history of subversion or terrorism
Crimes.Application_Facts: Gebreab joined EPRP in 1986, after its violent phase in the 1970s; Board found EPRP to be a continuous organization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether the correct legal test for organizational continuity was applied
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Historical activities of EPRP in the 1970s, organizational structure and continuity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; focus on organizational continuity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible due to membership in EPRP
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Immigration Division's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for factual findings, correctness for legal test
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: EPRP considered a continuous organization that had engaged in subversion; membership triggers inadmissibility regardless of timing
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Application_Facts: Gebreab joined EPRP in 1986 when it was not violent; Board found EPRP’s 1970s activities sufficient to classify it as subversive
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Correctness of legal test for organizational continuity
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Historical record of EPRP’s 1970s subversive activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assessment focused on organization, not individual credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Found inadmissible due to EPRP’s past subversive acts
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Correctness for legal interpretation, reasonableness for factual findings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Organization’s past engagement in subversion is sufficient for inadmissibility, even if ceased before membership

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential risk due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in organization previously engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with EPRP, which committed terrorist acts in the 1970s
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorist and subversive acts in the 1970s
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Board accepted historical evidence of EPRP’s terrorist activities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Continuity of EPRP as an organization from 1970s to 1986
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and historical evidence of EPRP’s activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Focus on organizational conduct, not personal involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Timing of membership relative to violent period
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'engaged in terrorism' regarding organizational continuity
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada, judicial review dismissed

Dispute_Type: Procedural fairness in immigration admissibility decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant was denied procedural fairness in the decision regarding his daughter's admissibility
Outcome: Court ordered medical officers to provide a response to the applicant's questions by January 4, 1999
Legal_Provision: Requirements for procedural fairness in immigration decisions
Basis_of_Claim: Potential excessive demand on social services
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to disclose specific information about the medical opinion
Application_Error: Failure to provide applicant with basis of medical assessment
Assessment_Standard: Fair opportunity to respond to concerns
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's inability to respond due to lack of disclosed reasoning
Decision_Outcome: Order for disclosure and response from medical officers
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on identity verification
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision to reject claim due to failure to establish identity

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of bias; standard of reasonableness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving authenticity of identity documents

Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court (on review)

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision based on totality of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Widespread use of fraudulent documents in country of origin

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim with disputed identity verification
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board's finding regarding applicant's failure to prove identity

Crimes.Application_Factor: Totality of evidence related to identity

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer reasonably concluded the Applicant was a member of a terrorist organization
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Initial admission at port of entry, corroborating evidence, inconsistent denials
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Officer to establish reasonable grounds for belief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent statements by the Applicant affected credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Membership requires more than casual involvement
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Officer's decision

Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn inadmissibility finding
